title: Sneak Peeks
abstract:
Indexing in MarkLogic 5 and Beyond
Gajanan Chinchwadkar, MarkLogic
 
In the continuing quest for ever-faster query processing and analytics, MarkLogic 5 is packed with new indexing options. In this talk you will hear a Lead Engineer from MarkLogic describe the MarkLogic 5 indexing options, and he’ll give you a sneak peek into what he’s working on for future versions of MarkLogic. MarkLogic 5 contains value and range indexing options on fields, to support very fast structured, unstructured, and mixed queries. The talk will include a brief overview of field indexing, querying, and a detailed description of the new options and their uses. You’ll also hear about work that is under way to provide more flexible indexing in a future version of MarkLogic.
 
User Defined Functions
John Snelson, Lead Engineer, MarkLogic
 
Ever wanted to write a function in C++ and have it run in the MarkLogic process? What if you could access the range indexes directly from that function and – better yet – write your own in-database MapReduce functions? In this talk John Snelson describes UDFs, which he’s working on for a future release of MarkLogic.
 
Super Clusters
Wayne Feick, MarkLogic
Scalability is important for Big Data. In this session we’ll show a Technical Preview of super clusters, which will let you build a cluster of clusters and a database of databases. With a super cluster you’ll have a unified view over databases in several clusters, and you’ll be able to scale out even further than you can with a single cluster.
